reviews.review_text: I have read it twice now and am looking forward to No. 3.
Great read about Jamaica history. Love it.
Excellent book. I cannot wait until Seven Killings becomes a movie.

This novel is sweeping in its scope, telling the story of the violence in Jamaican politics, the death of Bob Marley and the rise of the Jamaican drug possession, all revealed in spurts and starts through the eyes of a disparate series of characters who come and go but who all leave an indelible mark on the novel. A history lesson told by an engaging ensemble cast on all sides of the crisis, from the jaded CIA operatives to the killers and the politicians that turned Jamaica into a bloodbath in the seventies an eighties, to the drug dealers that brought crack to inner city America. I really didn't expect to like this book as much as I did. I break books down into those I should read and those I can't wait to read. After reading this I have to say it fills both catagories. The darkness That pervades the book is almost unremitting, but it's a darkness that sucks you in and spits you out at the end with a Wow. Well worth the read, I really couldn't put it down. It's undoubtedly the best book I have red all year, though there are a few scenes that I would like to erase from my memory, lol.
Hard work. Brutal. Don't know if it was worth the effort.
James style is amazing.  Once you pick this book up you will be on the edge of your seat as each character tells the story in their words.
Gives a great background of the past political situation in Jamaica. Tough read, this isn't a quick beach read. But it's worth reading.

A Brief History of Seven Killings by Marlon James is definitely not brief (about 700 pages) and is probably not history – not exactly, anyway. A fictional, multi-voice account of the assassination attempt of Bob Marley in Jamaica in the 70’s during a time of major political turmoil, the story is told by a couple dozen “characters” involved, in their own words -- an utterly engaging and realistic read, and probably the best multi-voiced novel I’ve ever read. Frightening and horrific, the story is so real and so powerful and so vividly told. It’s like Marlon James takes the reader back in time to Jamaica’s underworld, introduces us to every character involved in this strange event, and lets him or her tell his or her part in the story directly to us. No explanations, footnotes, references or glossaries. Just an unforgettable story driven by extremely engaging voices of characters with whom you can’t help but empathize – even though some of them are killers and gangsters and spies and drug dealers and ghosts and (yikes) reporters. It’s a truly great book, in my opinion, and worth all of the hype and awards its received.It’s a fantastic piece of storytelling. And I won’t forget this book, this story or its characters (and their language) for a long, long time to come. I almost feel bad for Claudia Pineiro because I’m reading her book, A Crack in the Wall, next and she has to compete with this. Although, the first two chapters are promising.

summary:
A “thrilling, ambitious . . . intense” (Los Angeles Times) novel that explores the attempted assassination of Bob Marley in the late 1970s. 

In A Brief History of Seven Killings, Marlon James combines masterful storytelling with his unrivaled skill at characterization and his meticulous eye for detail to forge a novel of dazzling ambition and scope.

On December 3, 1976, just before the Jamaican general election and two days before Bob Marley was to play the Smile Jamaica Concert to ease political tensions in Kingston, seven unnamed gunmen stormed the singer’s house, machine guns blazing. The attack wounded Marley, his wife, and his manager, and injured several others. Little was officially released about the gunmen, but rumors abounded regarding the assassins’ fates. A Brief History of Seven Killings is James’s fictional exploration of that dangerous and unstable time in Jamaica’s history and beyond. 

Deftly spanning decades and continents and peopled with a wide range of characters—assassins, drug dealers, journalists, and even ghosts—James brings to life the people who walked the streets of 1970s Kingston, who dominated the crack houses of 1980s New York, and who reemerged into a radically altered Jamaica of the 1990s. 

Brilliantly inventive, A Brief History of Seven Killings is an “exhilarating” (The New York Times) epic that’s been called “a tour de force” (The Wall Street Journal).
